DVD0001;The Godfather;Classic;DVD;15.99 euros;1;American epic crime film directed by Francis Ford Coppola.;"In 1945
column2: the New York City Corleone family don
column3: Vito Corleone
column4: listens to requests during his daughter Connie's wedding to Carlo. Vito's youngest son Michael
column5: a former Marine who has thus far stayed out of the family business
column6: introduces his girlfriend
column7: Kay Adams
column8: to his family at the reception. Johnny Fontane
column9: a popular singer and Vito's godson
column10: seeks Vito's help in securing a movie role. Vito sends his consigliere
column12: to persuade studio president Jack Woltz to offer Johnny the part. Woltz refuses Hagen's request at first
column13: but soon complies after finding the severed head of his prized racing horse in his bed.

column1: As Christmas approaches
column2: drug baron Sollozzo asks Vito to invest in his narcotics business and for police protection. Vito declines
column3: citing that involvement in narcotics would alienate his political connections. Suspicious of Sollozzo's partnership with the Tattaglia crime family
column4: Vito sends his enforcer Luca Brasi to the Tattaglias on an espionage mission. Brasi is garroted to death during the initial meeting. Later
column5: enforcers gun down Vito and coerce Hagen into a meeting. With Vito's first-born Sonny now in command
column6: Sollozzo pressures Hagen to persuade Sonny to accept the narcotics deal. Vito survives the shooting and is visited in the hospital by Michael
column7: who finds him unprotected after NYPD officers on Sollozzo's payroll cleared out Vito's guards. Michael thwarts the attempt on his father's life but is beaten by corrupt police captain Mark McCluskey. After the attempted hit at the hospital
column8: Sonny retaliates with a hit on Bruno Tattaglia. Sollozzo and McCluskey request to meet with Michael and settle the dispute. Michael feigns interest and agrees to meet
column9: but hatches a plan with Sonny and Corleone capo Clemenza to kill them and go into hiding. Michael meets Sollozzo and McCluskey at a Bronx restaurant; after retrieving a handgun planted in the bathroom by Clemenza
column10: he shoots both men dead.

column1: Despite a clampdown by the authorities for the killing of a police captain
column2: the Five Families erupt in open warfare. Michael takes refuge in Sicily and Fredo
column3: Vito's second son
column4: is sheltered by Moe Greene in Las Vegas. Sonny publicly attacks and threatens Carlo for physically abusing Connie. When he abuses her again
column5: Sonny speeds to their home but is ambushed and murdered by gangsters at a highway toll booth. In Sicily
column6: Michael meets and marries a local woman
column7: Apollonia
column8: but she is killed shortly thereafter by a car bomb intended for him.

column1: Devastated by Sonny's death and tired of war
column2: Vito sets a meeting with the Five Families. He assures them that he will withdraw his opposition to their narcotics business and forgo avenging Sonny's murder. His safety guaranteed
column3: Michael returns home to enter the family business and marry Kay. Kay gives birth to two children in the early 1950s. With his father nearing the end of his life and Fredo not suited to lead
column4: Michael assumes the position of head of the Corleone family. Vito reveals to Michael that it was Don Barzini who ordered the hit on Sonny and warns him that Barzini would try to kill him at a meeting organized by a traitorous Corleone capo. With Vito's support
column5: Michael relegates Hagen to managing operations in Las Vegas as he is not a ""wartime consigliere"". Michael travels to Las Vegas to buy out Greene's stake in the family's casinos and is dismayed to see that Fredo is more loyal to Greene than to his own family.

column2: Vito dies of a heart attack while playing with Michael's son Anthony. At Vito's funeral
column3: Tessio asks Michael to meet with Barzini
column4: signaling his betrayal. The meeting is set for the same day as the baptism of Connie's baby. While Michael stands at the altar as the child's godfather
column5: Corleone hitmen murder the dons of the Five Families
column6: plus Greene
column7: and Tessio is executed for his treachery. Michael extracts Carlo's confession to playing a part in Sonny's murder. He assures Carlo that he is being exiled
column8: not murdered
column9: before Clemenza strangles Carlo. Connie confronts Michael about his involvement in Carlo's death while Kay is in the room. Kay asks Michael if she is telling the truth and is relieved when he denies carrying out the death. As she leaves
column10: capos enter the office and pay reverence to Michael as ""Don Corleone"".";Marlon Brando

column1: DVD0002;City Lights;Classic;DVD;10.99 euros;1;City Lights is a 1931 American silent romantic comedy-drama film written
column2: produced
column3: directed by
column4: and starring Charlie Chaplin.;"Citizens and dignitaries are assembled for the unveiling of a new monument to ""Peace and Prosperity"". After droning speeches
column5: the veil is lifted to reveal the Little Tramp asleep in the lap of one of the sculpted figures. After several minutes of slapstick
column6: he manages to escape the assembly's wrath to perambulate the city. He rebukes two newsboys who taunt him for his shabbiness
column7: and while coyly admiring a nude statue has a near-fatal encounter with a sidewalk elevator.

column1: The Tramp encounters the beautiful flower girl on a street corner and in the course of buying a flower realizes she is blind; he is instantly smitten. The girl mistakes the Tramp for a wealthy man when the door of a chauffeured automobile slams shut as he departs.
That evening the Tramp saves a drunken millionaire from suicide. The millionaire takes the Tramp – his new best friend – back to his mansion for champagne
column2: then (after another abortive suicide attempt) out for a night on the town. After helping the millionaire home the next morning
column3: he sees the flower girl en route to her street-corner. He gets some money from the millionaire and catches up to the girl; he buys all her flowers and drives her home in the millionaire's car.

column1: After the Tramp leaves
column2: the flower girl tells her grandmother about her kind and wealthy friend. Meanwhile
column3: the Tramp returns to the mansion
column4: where the millionaire – now sober – does not remember him and throws him out. Later that day
column5: the millionaire is once again intoxicated and
column6: seeing the Tramp on the street
column7: invites him home for a lavish party. But the next morning history repeats itself: the millionaire is again sober and the Tramp is again out on his ear.

column1: Finding that the girl is not at her usual street-corner
column2: the Tramp goes to her apartment
column3: where he overhears a doctor tell the grandmother that the girl is very ill: ""She has a fever and needs careful attention."" Determined to help
column4: the Tramp takes a job as a street sweeper.

column1: On his lunch break
column2: he brings the girl groceries while her grandmother is out selling flowers. To entertain her he reads a newspaper aloud; in it is a story about a Viennese doctor's blindness cure. ""Wonderful
column3: then I'll be able to see you""
column4: says the girl – and the Tramp is struck by what may happen should she gain her sight and discover that he is not the wealthy man she imagines. He also finds an eviction notice the girl's grandmother has hidden. As he leaves
column5: he promises the girl that he will pay the rent.

column1: The Tramp returns to work to find himself fired – he has been late once too often. A boxer convinces him to fight in a fake bout; they will ""go easy"" on each other and split the prize money. But the boxer flees on learning he is about to be arrested and is replaced by a no-nonsense fighter who knocks the Tramp out despite the Tramp's creative and nimble efforts to keep out of reach.

The Tramp encounters the drunken millionaire a third time and is again invited to the mansion. The Tramp relates the girl's plight and the millionaire gives him money for her operation. Burglars knock the millionaire out and take the rest of his money. The police find the Tramp with the money given to him by the millionaire
column2: who because of the knock on the head does not remember giving it. The Tramp evades the police long enough to get the money to the girl
column3: telling her he will be going away for a time; in due course he is apprehended and imprisoned.

column1: Months later the Tramp is released. He goes to the girl's customary street corner but she is not there. We learn that the girl – her sight restored – now runs a busy flower shop with her grandmother. But she has not forgotten her mysterious benefactor
column2: whom she imagines to be rich and handsome: when an elegant young man enters the shop she wonders for a moment whether ""he"" has returned.

column1: The Tramp happens by the shop
column2: where the girl is arranging flowers in the window. He stoops to retrieve a flower discarded in the gutter. After a brief skirmish with his old nemeses
column3: the newsboys
column4: he turns to the shop's window through which he suddenly sees the girl
column5: who has been watching him without (of course) knowing who he is. At the sight of her he is frozen for a few seconds
column6: then breaks into a broad smile. The girl is flattered and giggles to her employee
column7: ""I've made a conquest!"" Via pantomime through the glass she offers him a fresh flower (to replace the crushed one he took from the gutter) and a coin.

column1: Suddenly embarrassed
column2: the Tramp begins to shuffle away
column3: but the girl steps to the shop door and again offers the flower
column4: which he shyly accepts. She takes his hand and presses the coin into it
column5: then abruptly stops and her smile turns to a look of puzzlement as she recognizes the touch of his hand. She runs her fingers along his arm
column6: his shoulder
column7: his lapels
column8: then gasps
column9: ""You?"" The Tramp nods and asks
column10: ""You can see now?"" The girl replies
column13: and presses his hand to her heart with a tearful smile. Relieved and elated
column17: Harry Myers and Al Ernest Garcia

column1: DVD0003;Casablanca;Classic;DVD;15.99 euros;1;1942 American romantic drama;"In December 1941
column2: American expatriate Rick Blaine owns a nightclub and gambling den in Casablanca. ""Rick's Café Américain"" attracts a varied clientele
column3: including Vichy French and Nazi German officials
column4: refugees desperate to reach the neutral United States
column5: and those who prey on them. Although Rick professes to be neutral in all matters
column6: he ran guns to Ethiopia in 1935 and fought on the Loyalist side in the Spanish Civil War.

column1: Petty crook Ugarte boasts to Rick of letters of transit obtained by murdering two German couriers. The papers allow the bearers to travel freely around German-occupied Europe and to neutral Portugal. Ugarte plans to sell them at the club and persuades Rick to hold them. Before he can meet his contact
column2: Ugarte is arrested by the local police under Captain Louis Renault
column3: the unabashedly corrupt prefect of police. Ugarte dies in custody without revealing that Rick has the letters.

column1: Then the reason for Rick's cynical nature—former lover Ilsa Lund—enters his establishment. Spotting Rick's friend and house pianist
column2: Sam
column3: Ilsa asks him to play ""As Time Goes By"". Rick storms over
column4: furious that Sam disobeyed his order never to perform that song again
column5: and is stunned to see Ilsa. She is accompanied by her husband
column6: Victor Laszlo
column7: a renowned fugitive Czechoslovak Resistance leader. A flashback reveals Ilsa left Rick without explanation when the couple were planning to flee as the German army neared Paris
column8: embittering Rick. Laszlo and Ilsa need the letters to escape
column9: while German Major Strasser arrives in Casablanca to prevent just that.

column1: When Laszlo makes inquiries
column2: Signor Ferrari
column3: an underworld figure and Rick's friendly business rival
column4: divulges his suspicion that Rick has the letters. Laszlo returns to Rick's cafe that night and tries to buy them. Rick refuses to sell
column5: telling Laszlo to ask his wife why. They are interrupted when Strasser leads a group of German officers in singing ""Die Wacht am Rhein"". Laszlo orders the house band to play ""La Marseillaise"". When the bandleader looks to Rick
column6: the latter nods
column7: and Laszlo begins to sing. Patriotic fervor grips the crowd
column8: and everyone joins in
column9: drowning out the Germans. Afterwards
column10: Strasser has Renault close the club on a flimsy pretext.

column1: Later
column2: Ilsa confronts Rick in the deserted café; when he refuses to give her the letters
column3: she threatens him with a gun but then confesses that she still loves him. She explains that when they met and fell in love in Paris in 1940
column4: she believed her husband had been killed attempting to escape from a concentration camp. Then she learned that Laszlo was alive and hiding near Paris. She left Rick without explanation to nurse her sick husband. Rick's bitterness dissolves. He agrees to help
column5: letting her believe she will stay with him when Laszlo leaves. When Laszlo unexpectedly shows up
column6: having narrowly escaped a police raid on a Resistance meeting
column7: Rick has waiter Carl spirit Ilsa away. Laszlo
column8: aware of Rick's love for Ilsa
column9: tries to persuade him to use the letters to take her to safety.

column1: When the police arrest Laszlo on a trumped-up charge
column2: Rick persuades Renault to release him by promising to set him up for a much more serious crime: possession of the letters. To allay Renault's suspicions
column3: Rick explains that he and Ilsa will use the letters to leave for America. When Renault tries to arrest Laszlo as arranged
column4: however
column5: Rick forces him at gunpoint to assist in their escape. At the last moment
column6: Rick makes Ilsa board the plane to Lisbon with Laszlo
column7: telling her that she would regret it if she stayed
column8: ""Maybe not today
column9: maybe not tomorrow
column10: but soon and for the rest of your life."" Strasser
column12: drives up alone. When Strasser attempts to stop the plane
column13: Rick shoots him dead. Policemen arrive. Renault pauses
column14: then orders them to ""round up the usual suspects."" He suggests to Rick that they join the Free French in Brazzaville. As they walk away into the fog
column17: I think this is the beginning of a beautiful friendship.""";Humphrey Bogart

column1: DVD0004;Singin' in the Rain;Classic;DVD;15.99 euros;1;Singin' in the Rain is a 1952 American musical romantic comedy;"In 1927
column2: popular silent film stars Don Lockwood and Lina Lamont attend the premiere of their latest film The Royal Rascal. Though Don can barely tolerate Lina
column3: their studio
column4: Monumental Pictures
column5: links them romantically to increase publicity. Lina is convinced that they truly are in love
column6: despite Don's protestations otherwise. At a red-carpet interview
column7: Don relates the story of his rise to stardom
column8: though his words are contradicted by flashbacks showing his humble roots as a hoofer
column9: Vaudeville musician and stuntman
column10: alongside his best friend from boyhood Cosmo Brown (""Fit as a Fiddle"").

column1: After the premiere
column2: Don escapes rabid fans by jumping into a passing car driven by Kathy Selden. Kathy
column3: who claims to be a theater actress
column4: drops him off
column5: but not before deriding his accomplishments as a movie star.

column1: Later
column2: at an after-party
column3: Monumental Pictures head R. F. Simpson
column4: shows a short demonstration of the newfound talking picture.[a] His guests are unimpressed
column5: believing it will never amount to anything. To Don's amusement
column6: Kathy pops out of a mock cake
column7: revealing herself to be a chorus girl (""All I Do is Dream of You""). Furious at Don's teasing
column8: she throws a cake at him
column9: accidentally hitting Lina. Kathy runs away before Don can catch up with her.

column1: Weeks later
column2: Don is still smitten with Kathy and has been searching for her
column3: with Cosmo trying to cheer him up (""Make 'Em Laugh""). Lina reveals that she got Kathy fired. On the studio lot
column4: Cosmo finds Kathy working as an extra in another Monumental Pictures production (""Beautiful Girl""). Kathy admits to actually being a fan of Don's
column5: while Don professes his feelings for her (""You Were Meant for Me"").

column1: After rival studio Warner Bros. has an enormous hit with its first talking picture The Jazz Singer
column2: R. F. decides he has no choice but to convert the next Lockwood and Lamont film
column3: The Dueling Cavalier
column4: into a talkie; Lina and Don undertake diction lessons in preparation (""Moses Supposes""). The production is beset with difficulties
column5: including the actors being unfamiliar with the recording technology and Lina's grating
column6: high-pitched voice. Due to multiple complications (including awkward microphone placements
column7: Don's uninspired improvising[b] and the audio going out of sync)
column8: The Dueling Cavalier's preview screening is a failure.

column1: Afterward
column2: Kathy and Cosmo help Don come up with the idea to save The Dueling Cavalier by turning it into a musical (""Good Morning""). Cosmo
column3: inspired by the film's synchronization error
column4: suggests they dub Lina's voice with Kathy's. Don drops Kathy off at her home and then walks home through a driving rain. (""Singin' in the Rain""). Don and Cosmo pitch the idea to R. F.
column5: changing the title of the film to The Dancing Cavalier and adding a modern framing device (""Broadway Melody""). R. F. approves but tells them not to inform Lina that Kathy is doing the dubbing.

column1: Having learned the truth
column2: a furious Lina barges in on a dubbing session. She becomes even angrier after being told that Don and Kathy are in love and intend to marry
column3: and that R. F. intends to give Kathy a screen credit and a big publicity buildup. Lina threatens to sue R. F. unless he makes sure no one ever hears of Kathy and that she keeps dubbing Lina for the rest of her career. R. F. reluctantly agrees because of a clause in Lina's contract which holds the studio responsible for positive media coverage.

column1: The premiere of The Dancing Cavalier is a success (""Would You""). When the audience clamors for Lina to sing live
column2: Don
column3: Cosmo
column4: and R. F. tell her to lip sync into a microphone while Kathy
column5: concealed behind the curtain
column6: sings into a second one. While Lina is ""singing"" (""Singin' in the Rain Reprise"")
column7: Don
column8: Cosmo and R. F. open the curtain
column9: revealing the ruse. The defeated Lina flees in humiliation. A distressed Kathy tries to run away as well
column10: but Don proudly announces to the audience that she is ""the real star"" of the film (""You Are My Lucky Star""). Later
column11: Kathy and Don kiss in front of a billboard for their new film Singin' in the Rain.";Gene Kelly

column1: DVD0005;Vertigo;Hitchcock;DVD;15.99 euros;1;One of the most famous psychological thrillers directed and produced by Alfred Hitchcock;"After a rooftop chase in which a fellow policeman falls to his death
column2: San Francisco detective John ""Scottie"" Ferguson retires out of fear of heights and vertigo. His ex-fiancée says that another severe emotional shock may be the only cure.

column1: Gavin Elster
column2: an acquaintance from college
column3: asks Scottie to follow his wife
column4: Madeleine
column5: claiming that she has been behaving strangely. Scottie follows Madeleine to the Mission San Francisco de Asís and the grave of Carlotta Valdes (1831–1857)
column6: and to the Legion of Honor art museum
column7: where she gazes at the Portrait of Carlotta.

column1: A local historian explains that Carlotta Valdes committed suicide: she had been the mistress of a wealthy married man and borne his child; the otherwise childless man kept the child and cast Carlotta aside. Carlotta (who Gavin fears is possessing Madeleine) is Madeleine's great-grandmother
column2: although Madeleine has no knowledge of this and does not remember the places she visited. Scottie rescues her when she leaps into the bay at Fort Point.

column1: The next day
column2: Madeleine stops to deliver a letter of gratitude to Scottie
column3: and they spend the day together. They travel to Muir Woods and Cypress Point on 17-Mile Drive
column4: where they embrace. The next day
column5: Madeleine recounts a nightmare. Scottie identifies its setting as Mission San Juan Bautista
column6: the childhood home of Carlotta. He drives her there and they express their love for each other. Madeleine suddenly runs into the church and up the bell tower. Scottie
column7: halted by his fear of heights
column8: sees Madeleine plunge to her death.

column1: An inquest declares her death to be a suicide. Gavin does not fault Scottie
column2: but Scottie becomes clinically depressed and is sent to a sanatorium
column3: almost catatonic. Following his release
column4: he frequents the places Madeleine visited
column5: often imagining that he sees her. One day
column6: he notices a woman on the street who
column7: although superficially very different
column8: reminds him of Madeleine. She identifies herself as Judy Barton
column9: from Salina
column10: Kansas.

column1: A flashback reveals that Judy was the person Scottie knew as ""Madeleine Elster"". She was impersonating Gavin's wife in an elaborate murder scheme. Gavin took advantage of Scottie's fear of heights to substitute his wife's freshly-killed body in the apparent ""suicide jump"". Judy considers confessing to Scottie but continues the charade because she loves him.
They begin seeing each other
column2: but Scottie remains obsessed with ""Madeleine"". He asks Judy to change her clothes and dye her hair to resemble her. After she complies
column3: he notices her wearing the necklace portrayed in Carlotta's painting. He realizes the truth and drives Judy back to the Mission.

column1: There
column2: he tells her he must re-enact the event that led to his madness
column3: and admits he now knows that ""Madeleine"" and Judy are the same person and Judy was Gavin's mistress before being cast aside. He forces her up the bell tower and makes her admit her deceit. He reaches the top
column4: finally conquering his fear of heights. Judy confesses that Gavin paid her to impersonate a ""possessed"" Madeleine. She begs Scottie to forgive her. He embraces Judy
column5: but a shadowy figure — a nun investigating the noise — rises from the tower's trapdoor
column6: startling her. Judy lunges backward and accidentally falls to her death. Scottie
column7: bereaved once again but cured of his fear of heights
column8: stands on the ledge while the nun rings the mission bell.";James Stewart and Kim Novak

column1: DVD0006;Notorious;Hitchcock;DVD;15.99 euros;1;A movie between spy and noir directed and produced by Alfred Hitchcock in 1946;"In April 1946
column2: Alicia Huberman
column3: the American daughter of a convicted Nazi spy
column4: is recruited by government agent T. R. Devlin to infiltrate an organization of Nazis who have escaped to Brazil after World War II. When Alicia refuses to help the authorities
column5: Devlin plays recordings of her fighting with her father and insisting that she loves America.

column1: Devlin and Alicia meet at the track
column2: with Alexander watching from the grandstand.

column1: While awaiting the details of her assignment in Rio de Janeiro
column2: Alicia and Devlin fall in love
column3: though his feelings are complicated by his knowledge of her promiscuous past. When Devlin gets instructions to persuade her to seduce Alex Sebastian
column4: one of her father's friends and a leading member of the Farben executives
column5: Devlin fails to convince his superiors that Alicia is not fit for the job. Devlin is also informed that Sebastian once was in love with Alicia. Devlin puts up a stoic front when he informs Alicia about the mission. Alicia infers
column6: mistakenly
column7: that he was merely pretending to love her as part of his job.

column1: Devlin contrives to have Alicia meet Sebastian at a riding club. He recognizes her and invites her to dinner where he says that he always knew they would be reunited. Sebastian quickly invites Alicia to dinner the following night at his home
column2: where he will host a few business acquaintances. Devlin and Captain Paul Prescott of the US Secret Service tell Alicia to memorize the names and nationalities of everyone there. At dinner
column3: Alicia notices that a guest becomes agitated at the sight of a certain wine bottle
column4: and is ushered quickly from the room. When the gentlemen are alone at the end of the dinner
column5: this guest apologizes and tries to go home
column6: but another insists on driving him
column7: implying that he will kill him.

column1: Soon Alicia reports to Devlin
column2: ""You can add Sebastian's name to my list of playmates."" When Sebastian proposes
column3: Alicia informs Devlin; he coldly tells her to do whatever she wants. Deeply disappointed
column4: she marries Sebastian.

column1: Alicia takes the wine cellar key while Alexander dresses for the party. The gown is by Edith Head.
After she returns from her honeymoon
column2: Alicia is able to tell Devlin that the key ring her husband gave her lacks the key to the wine cellar. Devlin suggests that Alicia give a grand party and invite him
column3: so he can investigate. Alicia secretly steals the key from Sebastian's ring
column4: and Devlin and Alicia search the cellar. Devlin accidentally breaks a bottle; inside is black sand
column5: later proven to be uranium ore. Devlin takes a sample
column6: cleans up
column7: and locks the door as Sebastian comes down for more champagne. Sebastian is shocked and dismayed to see the two of them alone together. Devlin pretends to be drunk and tells Sebastian that in his drunken state he insisted that Alicia come down to the cellar with him. She confirms this story and adds that she acquiesced in order to prevent Devlin from making an embarrassing scene in front of the party guests. Devlin congratulates Sebastian on having won Alicia's love and respect
column8: and makes an exit.

column1: Sebastian realizes that the cellar key is missing from his key-ring
column2: but the next morning he sees that Alicia has reattached it during the night. Thoroughly alarmed
column3: he returns to the cellar
column4: he finds the glass and sand from the broken bottle.

column1: Now Sebastian has a problem: he must silence Alicia
column2: but cannot expose her without revealing his own blunder to the rest of the Nazi emigres
column3: who will certainly kill him if they learn that he has married an American agent. When Sebastian discusses the situation with his mother
column4: she suggests that Alicia ""die slowly"" by poisoning. They poison her coffee and she soon falls ill. Her illness worsens until she collapses and is taken to her room
column5: where the telephone has been removed. Too weak to leave
column6: she perceives that her husband is slowly poisoning her to death.

column1: Devlin
column2: alarmed by Alicia's continuing absence
column3: sneaks into Alicia's room
column4: where she tells him that Sebastian and his mother are poisoning her. Shocked into honesty by Alicia's peril
column5: he finally confesses his love for her
column6: and carries her out of the mansion in full view of Sebastian's co-conspirators. Sebastian and his mother go along with Devlin's story that Alicia must go to the hospital
column7: but the conspirators are not convinced. Outside
column8: Sebastian begs Devlin and Alicia to take him with them
column9: but they contemptuously drive away
column10: leaving him behind to suffer a grim fate at the hands of his fellow Nazis.";Cary Grant

column1: DVD0007;2001: A Space Odyssey;Science Fiction;DVD;18.99 euros;1;"An epic science fiction film produced and directed by Stanley Kubrick
column2: based on the novel ""The Sentinel"" from Arthur C.Clarke";"In a prehistoric veldt
column3: a tribe of hominins is driven away from its water hole by a rival tribe. The next day
column4: they find an alien monolith has appeared in their midst. The tribe then learns how to use a bone as a weapon and after their first hunt
column5: return to drive their rivals away with it.

column1: Millions of years later
column2: Dr. Heywood Floyd
column3: Chairman of the United States National Council of Astronautics
column4: travels to Clavius Base
column5: an American lunar outpost. During a stopover at Space Station 5
column6: he meets Russian scientists who are concerned that Clavius seems to be unresponsive. He refuses to discuss rumours of an epidemic at the base. At Clavius
column7: Heywood addresses a meeting of personnel to whom he stresses the need for secrecy regarding their newest discovery. His mission is to investigate a recently found artefact
column8: a monolith buried four million years earlier near the lunar crater Tycho. As he and others examine the object and are taking photographs
column9: it emits a high-powered radio signal.

column1: Eighteen months later
column2: the American spacecraft Discovery One is bound for Jupiter
column3: with mission pilots and scientists Dr. Dave Bowman and Dr. Frank Poole on board
column4: along with three other scientists in suspended animation. Most of Discovery's operations are controlled by HAL
column5: a HAL 9000 computer with a human-like personality. When HAL reports the imminent failure of an antenna control device
column6: Dave retrieves it in an extravehicular activity (EVA) pod
column7: but finds nothing wrong. HAL suggests reinstalling the device and letting it fail so the problem can be verified. Mission Control advises the astronauts that results from their backup 9000 computer indicate that HAL has made an error
column8: but HAL blames it on human error. Concerned about HAL's behaviour
column9: Dave and Frank enter an EVA pod so they can talk in private without HAL overhearing. They agree to disconnect HAL if he is proven wrong. HAL follows their conversation by lip reading.

column1: While Frank is outside the ship to replace the antenna unit
column2: HAL takes control of his pod
column3: setting him adrift. Dave takes another pod to rescue Frank. While he is outside
column4: HAL turns off the life support functions of the crewmen in suspended animation
column5: killing them. When Dave returns to the ship with Frank's corpse
column6: HAL refuses to let him back in
column7: stating that their plan to deactivate him jeopardises the mission. Dave releases Frank's body and opens one of the ship's airlocks with his remote manipulators. Lacking a helmet for his spacesuit
column8: he positions his pod carefully so that when he opens the pod's airlock
column9: he is propelled by the escaping air across the vacuum into Discovery's airlock. He enters HAL's processor core and begins disconnecting most of HAL's circuits
column10: ignoring HAL's pleas to stop. When he is finished
column11: a prerecorded video by Heywood plays
column12: revealing that the mission's actual objective is to investigate the radio signal sent from the monolith to Jupiter.

column1: At Jupiter
column2: Dave finds a third
column3: much larger monolith orbiting the planet. He leaves Discovery in an EVA pod to investigate. He is pulled into a vortex of coloured light and observes bizarre astronomical phenomena and strange landscapes of unusual colours as he passes by. Finally he finds himself in a large neoclassical bedroom where he sees
column4: and then becomes
column5: older versions of himself: first standing in the bedroom
column6: middle-aged and still in his spacesuit
column7: then dressed in leisure attire and eating dinner

column1: DVD0008;Blade Runner;Science Fiction;DVD;15.99 euros;1;"Science fiction film directed by Ridley Scott in 1982
column2: based on Philip K. Dick's 1968 novel """"Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?""""";"In 2019 Los Angeles
column3: former police officer Rick Deckard is detained by Officer Gaff

column6: Bryant. Deckard
column7: whose job as a ""blade runner"" was to track down bioengineered humanoids known as replicants and terminally ""retire"" them
column8: is informed that four replicants are on Earth illegally. Deckard begins to leave

column1: Bryant has Deckard meet with the CEO of the company that creates the replicants
column2: Eldon Tyrell
column3: so he can administer the test on a Nexus-6 to see if it works. Tyrell expresses his interest in seeing the test fail first and asks him to administer it on his assistant Rachael. After a much longer than standard test
column4: Deckard concludes privately to Tyrell that Rachael is a replicant who believes she is human. Tyrell explains that she is an experiment who has been given false memories to provide an ""emotional cushion""
column5: and that she has no knowledge of her true nature.

column1: In searching Leon's hotel room
column2: Deckard finds photos and a scale from the skin of an animal
column3: which is later identified as a synthetic snake scale. Deckard returns to his apartment where Rachael is waiting. She tries to prove her humanity by showing him a family photo
column4: but Deckard reveals that her memories are implants from Tyrell's niece
column5: and she leaves in tears.

column1: Replicants Roy and Leon meanwhile investigate a replicant eye-manufacturing laboratory and learn of J. F. Sebastian
column2: a gifted genetic designer who works closely with Tyrell. Pris locates Sebastian and manipulates him to gain his trust.

column4: who has disappeared from the Tyrell Corporation. Deckard spots Rachael in a crowd
column5: but he is ambushed by Leon

column8: during a discussion

column11: and she ultimately relents. Deckard leaves Rachael at his apartment and departs to search for the remaining replicants.

column1: Roy arrives at Sebastian's apartment and tells Pris that the other replicants are dead. Sebastian reveals that because of a genetic premature aging disorder
column2: his life will be cut short
column3: like the replicants that were built with a four-year lifespan. Roy uses Sebastian to gain entrance to Tyrell's penthouse. He demands more life from his maker

column5: praising Roy's advanced design and accomplishments in his short life. Roy kisses Tyrell and then kills him by crushing his skull. Sebastian tries to flee and is later reported dead.[nb 1]

column4: as Deckard's grip loosens

column1: DVD0009;Avatar;Science Fiction;DVD;15.99 euros;1;Epic science fiction film directed
column2: written
column3: co-produced
column4: and co-edited by James Cameron in 2009;"In 2154
column5: the natural resources of the Earth have been depleted and is suffering ecocide.[28] The Resources Development Administration (RDA) mines the valuable mineral unobtanium on Pandora
column6: a moon in the Alpha Centauri star system. Pandora
column7: whose atmosphere is inhospitable to humans
column8: is inhabited by the Na'vi
column9: 10-foot-tall (3.0 m)
column10: blue-skinned
column11: sapient humanoids that live in harmony with nature. To explore Pandora
column12: genetically matched human scientists use Na'vi-human hybrids called ""avatars"". Paraplegic Marine Jake Sully is sent to Pandora to replace his deceased identical twin
column13: who had signed up to be an operator. Avatar Program head Dr. Grace Augustine considers Sully inadequate but accepts him as a bodyguard.

column1: While escorting the avatars of Grace and Dr. Norm Spellman
column2: Jake's avatar is attacked by Pandoran wildlife
column3: and he flees into the forest
column4: where he is rescued by female Na'vi Neytiri. Suspicious of Jake
column5: she takes him to her clan. Neytiri's mother
column6: Mo'at
column7: the clan's spiritual leader
column8: orders her daughter to initiate Jake into their society. Colonel Miles Quaritch
column9: head of RDA's security force
column10: promises Jake that the company will restore the use of his legs if he provides information about the Na'vi and their gathering place
column12: under which is a rich deposit of unobtanium. Learning of this
column15: and Norm to an outpost. Jake and Neytiri fall in love as Jake is initiated into the tribe. He and Neytiri choose each other as mates. When Jake attempts to disable a bulldozer threatening a sacred Na'vi site
column16: Administrator Parker Selfridge orders Hometree destroyed. Despite Grace's argument that destroying Hometree could damage Pandora's biological neural network
column17: Selfridge gives Jake and Grace one hour to convince the Na'vi to evacuate.

column1: Jake confesses that he was a spy and the Na'vi take him and Grace captive. Quaritch's soldiers destroy Hometree
column2: killing many
column3: including Neytiri's father
column4: the clan chief. Mo'at frees Jake and Grace
column5: but they are detached from their avatars and imprisoned by Quaritch's forces. Pilot Trudy Chacón
column6: disgusted by Quaritch's brutality
column7: airlifts Jake
column8: Grace
column9: and Norm to Grace's outpost. Grace is shot during the escape. Jake regains the Na'vi's trust by connecting his mind to that of Toruk
column10: a dragon-like creature feared and revered by the Na'vi. At the sacred Tree of Souls
column11: Jake pleads with Mo'at to heal Grace. The clan attempts to transfer Grace into her avatar with the aid of the Tree of Souls
column12: but she dies. Supported by new chief Tsu'tey
column14: telling them to gather all the clans to battle the RDA. Quaritch organizes a strike against the Tree of Souls to demoralize the Na'vi. Jake prays to the Na'vi deity Eywa via a neural connection with the Tree of Souls. Tsu'tey and Trudy are among the battle's heavy casualties.

column1: The Na'vi are rescued when Pandoran wildlife unexpectedly join the attack and overwhelm the humans
column2: which Neytiri interprets as Eywa answering Jake's prayer. Quaritch
column3: wearing an AMP suit
column4: escapes his crashed aircraft and breaks open the avatar link unit containing Jake's human body
column5: exposing it to Pandora's poisonous atmosphere. As Quaritch prepares to slit Jake's avatar's throat

column7: who saves Jake from suffocation
column8: seeing his human form for the first time. With the exceptions of Jake
column9: Norm
column10: and a select few others
column11: all humans are expelled from Pandora. Jake is permanently transferred into his avatar with the aid of the Tree of Souls.";Sam Worthington

column1: DVD0010;Finding Nemo;Animation;DVD;12.99 euros;1;Computer-animated comedy-drama adventure movie produced by Pixar Animation Studios for Walt Disney Pictures in 2003;"Clownfish Marlin lives in an anemone in the Great Barrier Reef with his partner
column2: Coral. The couple are awaiting for their many eggs to hatch. A hungry barracuda sees Coral and Marlin
column3: with the rest of their neighbourhood hiding. Coral fears she will lose her babies and rushes down to protect them
column4: encouraging the barracuda to eat Coral and most of their eggs
column5: knocking Marlin out in the process when he tries to protect Coral. One egg remains uneaten
column6: with it being slightly cracked. Marlin vows to keep his only surviving child safe. Marlin becomes overprotective of his son

column8: Nemo approaches a speedboat
column9: where a pair of scuba divers capture him. Marlin pursues the boat in vain and meets Dory
column10: a blue tang with acute short-term memory loss
column11: who offers her help. The two encounter Bruce
column14: three sharks who have sworn to abstain from eating fish. Marlin finds a diver's mask that fell from the boat
column15: accidentally hitting Dory and giving her a nosebleed. The scent of her blood sends Bruce into a feeding frenzy
column16: but the sharks flee after accidentally setting off old naval mines
column17: which knock Marlin and Dory unconscious.

column1: Nemo is placed in a Fish Tank in the office of dentist Philip Sherman in Sydney. He meets the ""Tank Gang"" led by Gill
column2: a Moorish idol. The Tank Gang tells Nemo that he will be given to Sherman's niece
column3: Darla
column4: who killed her previous fish. Gill decides to help Nemo and devises an escape plan: Nemo can fit inside the aquarium's filter tube and must block it with a pebble
column5: obliging Sherman to put the fish into plastic bags while he cleans the tank. This will allow them to roll out the window and into the harbor. Nemo attempts to place the pebble
column6: but fails and is almost killed.

column1: Marlin and Dory awaken

column7: including Crush and his son

column10: and soon
column11: the aquarium is covered in green algae.

column1: Marlin and Dory exit the East Australian Current and are consumed by a blue whale which expels them through its blowhole into Sydney Harbour. Nigel helps them escape a flock of seagulls and takes them to the dentist's office
column2: where Sherman has foiled the Tank Gang with a new high-tech filter. When Darla arrives

column8: Anchor
column9: and Chum. Marlin and Dory watch Nemo off as he goes to school. Meanwhile
